content: The "Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998" allows for the licensing of federally owned inventions under cooperative research and development agreements. The "Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998" allows for the licensing of federally owned inventions under cooperative research and development agreements. Section 209 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to grant exclusive or partially exclusive licenses on federally owned inventions under certain conditions. The Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998 allows for licensing of federally owned inventions under certain conditions, including commitment to practical utilization, no substantial competition lessening, and enhancement of US interests in foreign commerce. The Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998 allows for licensing of federally owned inventions in the United States with a requirement for manufacturing products substantially in the country. Small businesses are given preference for exclusive licenses, and terms and conditions of licenses are determined by the granting agency. The Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998 allows for licensing of federally owned inventions in the United States with provisions for the Federal agency to retain a nontransferrable, irrevocable, paid-up license and requiring periodic reporting on utilization of the invention by the licensee. The agency can terminate the license if the licensee fails to achieve practical utilization of the invention. The Federal agency can terminate the license if the licensee fails to achieve practical utilization of the invention, is in breach of an agreement, fails to meet public use requirements, or violates antitrust laws. The Federal agency must provide public notice before granting an exclusive or partially exclusive license on a federally owned invention. A basic business plan must be submitted by the person requesting the license for a federally owned invention. The agency requires a basic business plan with development milestones for licensing a federally owned invention, which is treated as confidential commercial information. Technical amendments to the Bayh-Dole Act include licensing federally owned inventions. Chapter 18 of title 35, United States Code, also known as the Bayh-Dole Act, is amended to allow Federal agencies to consolidate rights in inventions made under funding agreements with nonprofit organizations or small business firms. This includes the ability to license or assign rights to the nonprofit organization or small business firm, or acquire rights in the invention from the employee. Additionally, section 207(a) is amended to remove references to patent applications and patents. The Bayh-Dole Act is amended to allow Federal agencies to consolidate rights in inventions made under funding agreements with nonprofit organizations or small business firms. This includes acquiring rights for the Federal Government in any invention to facilitate the licensing of a federally owned invention. SEC. 5 of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 is amended to include provisions regarding inventor rights assigned to the United States and extending the timeframe for fiscal years. SEC. 6 involves a review of cooperative research and development agreement procedures. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, in consultation with relevant agencies, reviews federal agency policies on joint work statements and cooperative research agreements involving national security technology or competitiveness. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will assess existing procedures for interagency coordination and establish criteria for gathering agency views on joint work statements or cooperative research agreements. Procedures under this subsection aim to streamline processes, reduce agency burdens, promote partnerships with national laboratories, and expedite approval of joint work statements and research agreements. Passed the House of Representatives on July 14, 1998. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
